reviews.review_text: Dear [Insert horror game developer],  THIS is how I like my horror.  I received a good deal of flak for my (I admit) petty review of the Amnesia series of games, and while I understand that they were useless reviews, Close Your Eyes showed me exactly what I wanted to say about them but never knew I was looking for.  I wanted to love the amnesia series so much; I think a lot of horror games have some beautiful narratives hidden inside them, but they are all unplayable. You can call me a chicken or whatever you like, but jump scares are NOT fun. They are NOT horror. All they are is an involuntary reflex forced upon us by extreme stimuli. True horror makes you uncomfortable, afraid, uneasy and anxious. Sure you may jump sometimes but it’s because you did it to yourself. The game didn’t flash a light in your eyes and accompany it with a blood curdling snarl, no, the atmosphere puts you into a very unsafe place mentally and you begin to see and anticipate things on your own. This is what Close Your Eyes nails; I want so much more of this on the market that I don’t even know how to express myself. From the very beginning I was uneasy, the world was dark and simplistic, my mind filled in details that may or may not have even been there. The sound design and voice acting was chilling and spot on, causing countless chills and rushing adrenaline. Everything done in this game felt deliberate and calculated, not once did the developer cash in and sacrifice atmosphere and narrative for a PewDieBait jump scare. Nor did it need to. Much like the outstanding Point and Click game “The Cat Lady”, Close Your Eyes masterfully brings you into a very dark place and lets your mind take care of the rest - cruelly prodding it along with snippets of story and hints of progression.  Close Your Eyes is one of the best horror experiences I’ve had in recent memory. And as if I can’t praise it enough, it’s FREE. There is no reason (outside of mature content concerns) that anyone should pass up on a chance to experience this game. Bravo, Developers, bravo.

If any of you are triggered by death, blood, sitophilia, murder, hanging, ♥♥♥♥, seven deadly sins for all those religious folks out there, paranormal beings, gore, creepy music, jumpscares, close-to necrophilia, and mass-murder or sacrifice, you probably shouldn't play this game.  The puzzles in this game were surely difficult, and had your mind running. The characters in this game were a lot of fun to see develop as the game went along. The music that went along with this game surely did a great job of keeping you on the edge. It created a very nice ambience.  I thoroughly enjoyed this game, and I suggest you play it, as well! I suggest you do put a age-lock on this game though, seeing as it is not suited for non-mature audiences. Great Horror game! the visuals might not be remotely impressive but Close Your Eyes has good story, great audio, and amazing voice acting. The puzzles however range in difficult from really easy to convoluted and bothersome, so there is something there for everyone. Most importantly of all is the game is of decent length. it has multiple endings (I have only played through once) and it is really truly free!

Damn. I know I don't swear; but let me explain, a word like that can only describe the simplistic excellence this game achieves in my opinion. I have been waiting for a longer multi-ending storyline game since I finished the Stanley Parable. This game has restored my faith in video game storylines; I have been aching for a story like this. I loved this game so much it prompted me to write a review (which I haven't done in ages). It was perfect; it has a great story, puzzles, 7 different endings, a slight horror aspect, YET RETAINS THE ABILITY TO HAVE A SUFFICIENT AMOUNT OF GAMEPLAY (Which lately storyline games have LOST the ability to keep). All of the endings take at least 3 hours to complete, however so far I have only found one. Another great aspect: its price, absolutely free (but honestly I would pay money for it if it improved its art)(and its DLC), speaking of art for you graphics buffs: LAY OFF for god’s sake there hasn't been a game like this in AGES so disregard the art. I loved this title, and would love to see a soundtrack released. Not to mention provided me with sufficient nostalgia; memories of bouncing around in an overhead third person game in black and white are thrust back to mind. Still an amazing game 1 year later

this game was uh... something special. good and creepy psychological/psychedelic horror with a few jump scares here and there. pretty decent riddles throughout the whole game (albeit, one was a direct ripoff of a silent hill puzzle) even made me put my old school crystalis dungeon-mapping skills to good use at one point. 7 different endings, (that aren't too difficult to achieve. never needed a walkthrough) to keep you intrigued for roughly 4-5 hours of gameplay. just a heads up though, this game is quite graphic in its descriptions. my only complaint is the gut-wrenchingly bad grammar in the dialog, the voice acting is great though. examples such as: could of/must of/should of; defaultly; seaped and buldging, jesus christ, some proof reading would have been nice. it seems to me like they're trying too hard to be David Lynch at times, but it's forgiveable given how good the rest of the game is, and come on, 5 hours of gameplay? from a freebie??? DO IT... FEEL AROUND INSIDE OF HER... THAT'S IT... GOOD BOY... GOOD BOY...

First off, this game is very well designed. It feels like inspiration was taken from Silent Hill in the enviroment sounds that give the creep factor. The story seems interesting, but, personally I was lost, as I really found it hard to actually realise who was who and what was going on. The Puzzles are well designed, but some were a little too hard or weren't clear, which did let it down slightly. Voice overs were done well, and really captured the character. However, as great as this game is, there are faults. The game starts off well, but soon becomes a crawl through dark corridoors searching for keys to more keys that unlock doors to MORE keys. This could have worked well, but, between these points, it seemed empty. As the game progresses, it just seemed to become more and more tangled. The story stopped making much sense, and I soon wondered why I was wandering so many surreal areas. Now, I did quit the game at the Valerie Maze, but, deciding I wouldn't be beaten, I went back, and I have to say, I was impressed. The game still doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me, but I think I have a vauge idea of what happened/is happening. The multiple endings to be found are a nice touch, but again, they just confused me slightly. I certainly hope there will be a sequel to this game!

This game is simply excellent. It is a horror game that focuses more on horror as opposed to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ jump scares. There are jump scares, of course, but they are not major, not many, and add to the game. Going in to the game, you know little about your character besides that you are a criminal that has just escaped death row. The plot is very dark, and will keep you wondering what the ♥♥♥♥ the plot even is. The game has seven endings, all of which I've completed and written a guide to. All seven endings took me around eight hours, but only since I had to find all (except for one) myself; a quick playthrough when you know exactly what you are doing to get one ending only takes about 30-40 minutes. Still, there is more to the game then that, of course; through the experience, you'll be left on the edge of your seat in anticipation of what is to come, and in the back of your seat, afraid of what is to come. The game is, of course, free, and I would personally have paid money to play this game. It does feature a cheap DLC that I have yet to play.
This is one of the most creative and engaging games I've played in a long time. It's not so much a 'scary' game as it is a though-provoking way of telling a story. Highly recommended.

I actually had pretty high expectations of this game, since it was so good rated and looked really interesting, but to be honest, for me the game was a big disappointment. The graphics were messy and the plot really confusing, and most of the time you just had no idea what to do, which made the gaming experiment pretty fast boring and frustrating. Also the game music was pretty much just a really short part of singing (or a simple short melody) looping all over again, quickly getting really annoying.

The narration was WAY TOO LOUD considering I generally keep volume low. Then, 'must of', seriously?  I'm assuming this singing is bad on purpose. Speaking of which, if you swap casettes the song should stop immediately, not fade out.  I just tried to talk to a character and went right through it, I'm going to assume that's intentional for now.  The egg question is unfair, as it depends on the situation. Devilled eggs are awesome, but not for breakfast, and the GOAT egg option, basted, wasn't even there.  The skull puzzle is missing something. 'Maybe there's a clue' but I examined everything and found nothing for clues. Eventually randomly found the correct way by trying every direction.  I understand going to the TV is supposed to be game over, but whatever flashes on-screen is too quick to see. Why?  Ugh, the manor keyhunt got boring fast. Maybe I'll finish it another day but for now I'm done.

There are sevn endings, supposedly, so you can play this multiple times.. although I don't know why you would want to. It's actually a decent game, but it moves too slow. The last thing you want from an atmospheric horror is to get bored. Close my eyes? Only because these repetitive puzzles are putting me to sleep! Ahaha!
